The Committee on Appropriations amends Section 302(b) of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to include committee suballocations in an original joint resolution on appropriations allocations after consulting with the other House's Committee on Appropriations. The joint resolution specifies allocation of budget outlays and new budget authority among subcommittees and distinguishes between controllable amounts and other amounts. The joint resolution, as per the amended Section 302(b) of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974, specifies budget allocations among subcommittees, distinguishing between controllable amounts and other amounts. Debate in the Senate on such joint resolutions is limited to 20 hours, managed by the Committee on Appropriations. The joint resolution under the amended Section 302(b) of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 allocates budget among subcommittees, with debate limited to 20 hours and managed by the Committee on Appropriations. The allocations of the Committees on Appropriations only take effect once the joint resolution becomes law. Other committees must subdivide their allocations among subcommittees or programs, distinguishing between controllable amounts and other amounts. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 requires committees to subdivide budget allocations among subcommittees or programs, distinguishing between controllable amounts and other amounts. Any alterations to allocations proposed by the Committee on Appropriations must be approved. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 requires approval for any alterations to allocations proposed by the Committee on Appropriations. The committee can report alterations to allocations after reporting the required allocations, which must align with actions taken by the House on relevant legislation. SEC. 3. AMENDMENTS TO APPROPRIATIONS BILL. Section 302 of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to allow floor amendments to appropriations bills that reduce budget authority and relevant subcommittee allocations for the fiscal year covered by the bill. The bill amends Section 302 of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to allow floor amendments to appropriations bills that reduce budget authority, subcommittee allocations, and discretionary spending limits for the fiscal year covered by the bill and the following four fiscal years. It also sets restrictions on conference reports for appropriations bills that do not include sufficient reductions in allocations and spending as passed by the Senate or the House of Representatives. The bill amends Section 302 of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to allow floor amendments to appropriations bills that reduce budget authority, subcommittee allocations, and discretionary spending limits. It also imposes restrictions on conference reports for appropriations bills that lack necessary reductions in allocations and spending as passed by the Senate or the House of Representatives. The bill amends Section 602(b)(1) of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to require the Committee on Appropriations of each House to make suballocations in accordance with section 302(b)(1).
